abstract.text: An object that prepares for and performs the visual transition between two view controllers.

platforms.message: Loading Interface Builder products will not be supported in a future version of visionOS.
platforms.name: visionOS

inlineContent.text: class supports the standard visual transitions available in UIKit. You can also subclass to define custom transitions between the view controllers in your storyboard file.

Segue objects contain information about the view controllers involved in a transition. When a segue is triggered, but before the visual transition occurs, the storyboard runtime calls the current view controller’s
method so that it can pass any needed data to the view controller that’s about to be displayed.

You don’t create segue objects directly. Instead, the storyboard runtime creates them when it must perform a segue between two view controllers. You can still initiate a segue programmatically using the
if you want. You might do so to initiate a segue from a source that was added programmatically and therefore not available in Interface Builder.

in situations where you want to provide a custom transition between view controllers in your application. To use your custom segue, create a segue line between the appropriate view controllers in Interface Builder and set its type to Custom in the inspector; you must also specify the class name of the segue to use in the inspector.

When the storyboard runtime detects a custom segue, it creates a new instance of your class, configures it with the view controller objects, asks the view controller source to prepare for the segue, and then performs the segue.
For custom segues, the main method you need to override is the
method. The storyboard runtime calls this method when it’s time to perform the visual transition from the view controller in
. If you need to initialize any variables in your custom segue subclass, you can also override the
method and initialize them in your custom implementation.
If your segue doesn’t need to store additional information or provide anything other than a

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An encapsulation of the design-time view controller graph represented in an Interface Builder storyboard resource file.
A specific type of segue for presenting content in a popover.
An object that prepares for and performs the visual transition between two view controllers.
The destination view controller for the segue.
The identifier for the segue object.
Initializes and returns a storyboard segue object for use in performing a segue.
Creates a segue that calls a block to perform the segue transition.
Performs the visual transition for the segue.
The source view controller for the segue.
An encapsulation of information about an unwind segue.
A handler block that contains the custom initialization code for a view controller you instantiate from a storyboard.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
Initiates the segue with the specified identifier from the current view controller’s storyboard file.
Notifies the view controller that a segue is about to be performed.
Pass data between view controllers during a segue, and programmatically control when segues occur.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Customizing the behavior of segue-based presentations

abstract.text: Configure an unwind segue in your storyboard file that dynamically chooses the most appropriate view controller to display next.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Dismissing a view controller with an unwind segue

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
